description: Application for the approval of Condition 5 (Construction Management Plan) of Planning Permission ref: 19/02167/FUL (Demolition of existing house and erection of 5 storey residential building comprising 4 x 3 bed and 1 x 2 bed self contained units with associated bins and cycle store) dated 31/01/2020
decision_conditions: That the applicant is informed that the submitted details, as set out above are agreed and that the condition, as noted above, is fully discharged.

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling. The site is located within the Coombe Wood Conservation Area.4 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received. RBK Transport Officer - No highways objection. A separate vehicle crossover application will be required.The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development;- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings;- The impact of the development on highways and transportation matters; and,- The impact of the development on designated heritage assets.DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposal would increase the height of the boundary treatment to the front of the site from 1.9m to 2.175m. Given that it would be a marginal increase that would sit lower in height than the boundary treatment at the adjoining property, and would make use of materials that are in keeping with the original dwelling, officers consider that it would appear a sympathetic and appropriate addition to the host property and would not appear out of keeping with the character and appearance of the surrounding area. AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: Given the nature of the proposal and relation to neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. TransportationPolicy T6 of the London Plan 2021 states that car parking should be restricted in line with levels of existing and future public transport accessibility and connectivity. The maximum standards as set out in policies T6.1 to T6.5 should be applied to development proposals.Policy DM9, Policy DM10 and the Council's Sustainable Transport SPD 2013 together require development proposals to comply with the car parking standards in the London Plan.Officer Comment: Officers note that the dropped kerb would meet the requirements set out in the Council's Vehicle Crossover Policy in terms of width and distance from the existing bus cage to the north. However, the proposal would raise the boundary treatment to the front of the site to a height of 2.175m from 1.9m. Although officers consider that there would be restricted visibility entering and leaving the site given the height of the boundary treatment, as the existing boundary treatment is also a height in excess of the recommendations set out in the Vehicle Crossover Policy officers consider this credible fallback position, and as such it would be unreasonable to refuse the proposed development.The applicant is advised that the applicant would be required to seek the approval of the Local Highway Authority with regards to the construction of the dropped kerb (as well as obtaining planning permission) in this case.HeritageSection 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) places a duty on local planning authorities to pay special attention to the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character and appearance of conservation areas, when considering development proposals that would affect land or buildings within them.Paragraphs 194 to 203 of the NPPF set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC 1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Core Strategy 2012 sets out the Council's commitment to preserve or enhance the existing heritage assets of the Borough through the promotion of high quality design and a focus on heritage-led regeneration. The Council will allow alterations which preserve or enhance the established character and architectural interest of a heritage asset, its fabric or its setting, and will ensure that development proposals affecting historic assets will use high quality materials and design features which incorporate or compliment those of the host building or the immediate area. Features of local importance and special interest will be respected through the consideration of form, scale, layout and detailed designs of a site, area or streetscape.Officer Comment: As noted above, officers conclude that the proposed development would not result in any harm to the significance of the Coombe Wood Conservation Area Conservation Area, but rather preserve it. As previously mentioned, the proposed development would be in keeping with host property and as such would maintain the character of the immediate surrounding area. Given no harm to heritage assets has been identified in this case, it is not necessary to weigh up the proposals against any public benefits.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The submitted application form shows that the proposal has already been started, please confirm it.If it has been started we require the application for a lawful development for an existing use.Please find the attached form.
